Mamdani, inaugurated as New York mayor, must now deliver on promises that secured his victory
byline: By Nicolas Chapuis (New York (United States) correspondent)
subhed: The young politician, the first Muslim to lead the largest city in the US and firmly on the left, filled his inauguration ceremony on Thursday with symbolic gestures. Elected on a pledge to make New York more affordable, he said he intends to govern 'expansively and audaciously.'

Trump declares US will 'come to their rescue' if Iran kills protesters
subhed: The US president added that his country is 'locked and loaded and ready to go' as protests that started over economic stagnation and inflation sweep across Iran.

title: Israel halts the work of humanitarian NGOs in occupied Palestinian territories
byline: By Luc Bronner (Jerusalem, correspondent) and Stéphanie Maupas (The Hague, correspondence)
subhed: Aid organizations operating in Gaza and the West Bank were required to submit lists of their Palestinian staff to the Israeli administration by December 31 for vetting by intelligence services. Thirty-seven of these organizations have already lost their accreditation.

title: Why France still struggles to protect domestic violence victims
subhed: More than six years after the round tables on domestic violence – organized to improve prevention, detection and punishment of abuse – advocacy groups warn that the system is now at a breaking point.

title: How four years of war in Ukraine redefined the European Union
subhed: With Russia's aggression against Ukraine, the world that saw the construction of EU has all but disappeared. The 27 member states belatedly recognized that peace was 'no longer a given in Europe,' and awoke to their military weakness and energy dependence.

Early Christian fresco depicting Jesus as the Good Shepherd discovered in Turkey
subhed: One month after Pope Leo XIV's visit, Turkish authorities announced the discovery in Iznik, Anatolia, of a depiction of Christ in a well-preserved burial chamber.

title: 'I did it for the money, but I wasn't proud': Parties that hire 'dwarves' for entertainment
subhed: Hiring women or men of short stature to 'spice up' parties has become increasingly common in Europe in recent years. These practices raise both moral and legal questions.

title: 'We went through hell': Sudan's capital Khartoum slowly comes back to life
subhed: War in Sudan: A Trapped Nation (2/6). After serving as the civil war's frontline for two years, Khartoum was retaken by the official army in March. Since then, the city has been struggling to rise from its ashes.
